History of Present Illness:
___ with past medical history of AFib recently started

MSSA/S. hominus bacteremia and recurrent admission from 
___
for acute on chronic hypoxic resp failure and MSSA PNA requiring
intubation, multi-organ dysfunction, and recurrent MSSA
bacteremia (thought to be from R ___ toe osteo) discharged on 6
week course of cephazoline who represented on ___ from rehab
 for a rash c/f leukocytoclastic vasculitis ___ infection vs.
cefazolin, found to have CoNS/Bacillus bacteremia c/f 
contaminant
vs. PICC line infection treated with vanc, HFpEF exacerbation,
pseudomonas UTI, ___, course c/b severe C diff (___), slow GIB
thought to be due C diff, VRE bacteremia (thought from GI
translocation and endocarditis) on dapto and ceftaroline, and
most recently severe thrombycytopenia thought to be drug-induced
from antibiotics who developed an episode of hemoptysis 
yesterday
and developed acute on chronic hypoxic respiratory failure
requiring transfer to the MICU, thought to be related to DAH. 

Per primary team, on ___ patient had precipitous drop in
platelets from 156 -> 23 of initially unclear etiology. Heme/onc
was consulted and feel this is not likely a hemolytic process 
and
most likely drug-induced from either flagyl or ceftaroline (both
stopped). HIT antibody screen negative, fibrinogen and
haptoglobin normal. On ___, patient had an episode of 
hemoptysis
where he coughed up a quarter-sized clot but was otherwise
stable. He received platelet transfusions on ___ and ___ with
torsemide due to concern for ongoing slow GI bleed and episode 
of
hemoptysis respectively. On morning of ___, patient developed
acute hypoxic respiratory distress requiring non-rebreather for
desaturations down to ___. Labs were notable for a slightly
increased leukocytosis to 10 from 8.4, stable hgb, VBG 7.25/60.
CXR at time of decompensation showed pulm vascular congestion 
and
possible worsening R-sided consolidation. 

 
Past Medical History:
Afib (recently restarted on warfarin iso emboli)
Aortic valve replacement 
Peripheral vascular disease
HFpEF
Embolic CVA (___)
DM 
HTN
Arthritis 
Bilateral knee replacement

___ Admission to ___ for multiorgan failure, course c/b 
multiple brain emboli thought to be from aortic atheroma. Course 
complicated by MSSA bloodstream infection, Afib with RVR, 
rhabdomyolysis leading to acute renal failure requiring HD, and

   C. difficile PCR (Final ___: 
      Reported to and read back by ___ ON ___ AT 
1350. 
      POSITIVE.              (Reference Range-Negative). 
         The C. difficile PCR is highly sensitive for toxigenic 
strains of
         C. difficile and detects both C. difficile infection 
(CDI) and
         asymptomatic carriage. Therefore, positive C. diff PCR 
tests
         trigger reflex C. difficile toxin testing, which is 
highly
         specific for CDI.

RELEVANT IMAGING:
================
___
IMPRESSION:  
  
No evidence of deep vein thrombosis in the left upper extremity. 

  
___ 
IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Mild LVH with normal LV 
systolic function. Well seated bioprosthetic aortic valve with 
normal gradient. Trace aortic regurgitation. At least mild to
moderate mitral regurgitation, may be underestimated. Mild 
tricuspid regurgitaiton. Mild pulmonary hypertension. Resting 
tachycardia in setting of apparent atrial fibrillation.
Compared with the prior TTE (images reviewed) of ___ 
previous study is limited with suboptimal image quality limiting 
comparison. Current gradient across the bioprostetic aortic 
valve is normal. LVOT
diameter meausurement likely underestimated on prior. MR not 
well assessed on prior.

RECOMMEND: If clinically indicated, a TEE is suggested for 
further evaluation of endocarditis.

___ 
IMPRESSION: 
  
  
1. No acute hemorrhage or evidence for other acute intracranial 
abnormalities. 
No findings to suggest intracranial abscess on noncontrast CT. 
2. Small amount of fluid in the left mastoid tip air cells, 
which may be 
secondary to prolonged supine positioning in the inpatient 
setting.  Infection cannot be excluded in the setting of 
bacteremia.  However, no evidence for mastoid septal erosion to 
suggest confluent mastoiditis. 
  
___ CT chest w/o contrast
IMPRESSION:  
  
Combination of pulmonary edema and infectious process. 
  
Bilateral pleural effusions, loculated on the left, small and 
minimal on the right.  Adjacent areas of atelectasis in 
particular in the left lower lung. 
  
No appreciable abnormalities in the upper abdomen. 
  
Status post aortic valve replacement, extensive Coronary 
calcifications, most likely previous CABG. 

___ TEE 
Small mobile mass on the posterior mitral valve leaflet which 
may represent
mitral valve endocarditis or thrombus. Well-seated, normally 
functioning bioprosthetic aortic valve. Cannot exclude 
bioprosthetic aortic valve endocarditis. Mild mitral 
regurgitation. Simple
atheroma in the aortic arch with complex atheroma in the 
descending thoracic aorta.
Compared with the prior TEE ___, the small mitral valve 
mass seen on this study is not clearly visualized on the prior. 
Definitive comparison of the possible bioprosthetic aortic valve 
mass
cannot be made due to limited views on the prior study. There is 
less mitral regurgitation on this study.
Other findings are similar.

___ ___
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
No evidence of deep venous thrombosis in the right or left lower 
extremity 
veins. 

___ CXR
IMPRESSION:  
  
There is no evidence of acute intracranial process or 
hemorrhage. 
  
___ TTE
There is no evidence for a right-to-left shunt with agitated 
saline at rest. Overall left ventricular systolic
function is normal. Mildly dilated right ventricular cavity with 
moderate global free wall hypokinesis. An aortic
valve bioprosthesis is present. The prosthesis is well seated 
with normal leaflet motion. The mitral valve
leaflets are mildly thickened. The tricuspid valve leaflets 
appear structurally normal. There is mild [1+]
tricuspid regurgitation. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic 
hypertension.
IMPRESSION: No right-to-left flow of agitated saline at rest. 
Right ventricular cavity dilation with
free wall hypokinesis. Well seated bioprosthetic aortic valve.

___ CHEST (PORTABLE AP)  
Mostly resolved consolidation in the right upper lobe.  Some 
improvement in left basilar opacification.  Similar diffuse 
interstitial abnormality.

Brief Hospital Course:
===========================
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES 
===========================
[] Please encourage Mr. ___ to get a sleep study at next 
PCP follow up. ___ seems to be a longstanding problem that has 
affected his quality of life. 
[] Repeat CBC in 1 week to monitor anemia and WBC. Discharged 
with WBC 10.3 (from 6.7) without any new infectious symptoms
[] Please schedule colonoscopy given anemia and episode BRBPR 
early on in hospitalization.
[] Please continue taking daptomycin to be finished ___ ___s PO vancomycin, to be finished 10 days after completion of 
daptomycin on ___.
[] Trend CK level biweekly (next check ___ need to alter 
Daptomycin dosing vs. transition to another agent
[] Holding statin while on Daptomycin. Resume once finished. 

===========================
BRIEF SUMMARY 
===========================
___ PMH HTN, AS s/p AVR (tissue), AFib on warfarin, DM, recent 
admission for multi-organ dysfunction ___ emboli from aortic 
atheroma and sepsis, CVA, rhabdomyolysis, ___ requiring CRRT, 
NSTEMI, ischemic toe, who was transferred from a long-term acute 
care hospital due to acute onset of scattered macules throughout 
lower extremities diagnosed with leukocytoclastic vasculitis. He 
was treated for bloodstream infection ___ VRE with IV Daptomycin 
with course further complicated by acute hypoxemic respiratory 
failure ___ HFpEF exacerbation, ___, anemia, and afib with RVR.

#Acute on Chronic Hypoxic Resp Failure
#HFpEF (EF>55%)
Acute decompensated on the floor with SpO2 to the ___ requiring 
NRB, stabilized on high flow nasal cannula and weaned to 4L O2 
by NC with diuresis. Etiology of decompensation thought to be 
DAH given hemoptysis and severe thrombocytopenia, and pulm edema 
given CXR with stable pulm vascular congestion. Chest CT with 
multifocal infiltrates likely hemorrhage or aspiration 
pneumonitis. CTA was negative for PE. DAH resolved given 
improved platelet count. Volume overload treated with diuresis, 
initially IV lasix descalated to Torsemide PO.

# VRE bacteremia
# Presumed endocarditis
Possible prosthetic aortic valve endocarditis on TEE in ICU. Was 
previously on IV dapto and Ceftaroline for synergistic effect on 
VRE, but ceftaroline d/c ___ for concern for DITP as below. 
treated with IV daptomycin (___) with bi-weekly CK checks 
per ID recommendations. If CK continues to rise, may require 
alternative regimen or further daptomycin adjustments 

# AFib 
# Tachycardia
CHADS2Vasc = 6. Chronic AFib with multiple potential rhythms, 
including AFib (rate controlled in ___ and ATach vs. Aflutter 
(rate 130s). Several self-resolving episodes of RVR this 
admission. Started warfarin on last admission due to showering 
emboli. Pt switched to heparin gtt at the beginning of this
admission, then to apixaban (___) which was discontinued during 
epside of DITP and subsequent DAH. Apixiban restarted ___ with 
return of normal platelet count and no further episodes of 
hemoptysis or overt bleeding. Rate controlled in 90-110s with 
metopolol 50 mg Q6H and diltiazem 30 mg TID.

#Asymptomatic Severe Thrombocytopenia - resolved
#Acute blood loss anemia
On ___ patient had precipitous drop in platelets from 156 -> 23 
of initially unclear etiology. Heme/onc was consulted and felt 
this was not likely a hemolytic process and most likely 
drug-induced from either flagyl or ceftaroline (both stopped). 
HIT antibody screen negative, fibrinogen and haptoglobin normal.
Required total of 2U pletelets. Also had intermittently 
downtrending hgb over this admission thought to be slow GI 
oozing from severe C. diff. Received 1u pRBCS on ___ and again 
___. Platelets returned to ___ ___. H/H remained stable 
after which. Will need outpatient colonoscopy 

# CAD s/p CABG (LIMA-LAD, SVG-RCA)
# PVD
Continued home ASA, but held home atorvastatin given daptomycin 
use.

# C diff
# Frequent loose bowel movements
Toxin and PCR positive ___, coincided with onset of multiple 
soft stools with small amount of blood. Also had decrease in 
diarrhea following removal of ceftaroline suggesting abx 
associated diarrhea. Started PO vancomycin with resolution of 
diarrhea once transferred to medicine floor. PO vancomycin to be 
continued through ___.

#Anxiety
Patient has a history of anxiety and follows psychiatry 
outpatient. On sertraline at home. Related that he had been 
increasingly anxious since admission given his deterioration in 
health. Started seroquel 25 mg QHS:prn as well as trazaodone and 
ramelteon for sleep with improvement in mood. Avoided 
benzodiazepines and placed patient on delirium precautions. Held 
off on Seroquel on discharge as patient not using, but could 
consider if persistent anxiety.

CHRONIC/RESOLVED ISSUES:
========================
# Leukocytoclastic vasculitis
Likely ___ cefazolin vs. infectious etiology on admission. Rash 
had resolved by time of transfer to medicine floor.

# Elevated troponin
Elevated on presentation, 0.48 -> 0.52, peak TNT 0.61. Likely 
due
to demand ischemia, with ED EKG difficult to interpret and
subsequent EKG showing no ischemic changes.

# T2DM
Continued ISS.

30.  Simethicone 80 mg PO QID:PRN Bloating  
31.  Sodium Chloride 0.9%  Flush ___ mL IV DAILY and PRN, line 
flush  
32.  TraZODone 25 mg PO QHS:PRN Sleep  
33.  Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY  
34.  Zinc Sulfate 220 mg PO DAILY  
35. HELD- Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM  This medication was held. 
Do not restart Atorvastatin until you follow up with your doctor 
due to reaction with Daptomycin

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Rash (leukocytoclastic vasculitis)
Heart Failure 
Bloodstream Infection
Urinary Tract Infection
Atrial Fibrillation
Sleep Apnea

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___, 

===================================
WHY DID YOU COME TO THE HOSPITAL?
===================================
You came to the hospital for a rash on your legs.

================================
WHAT HAPPENED AT THE HOSPITAL?
================================
-Your rash was evaluated by the dermatology and vascular surgery 
teams. 
-You were found to have a bloodstream infection, which was 
treated with antibiotics.
-Your heart failure was treated with medications
-You were given oxygen to help with your breathing. 
-Your blood counts were low and we gave you units of blood to 
bring your counts back up. 
-You had a urinary tract infection which was treated with 
antibiotics.
-You had a bleed in your lungs that was a result of low 
platelets caused by a reaction to some of the antibiotics you 
were initially on
-Your atrial fibrillation was better controlled with medications 
and anticoagulation

====================================================
WHAT NEEDS TO HAPPEN WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL?
=====================================================
-Please follow up with your primary care physician as below.
-If you notice any of the danger signs listed below, please 
contact your PCP or go to an emergency room immediately.

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay!

Sincerely, 

Your ___ medical team

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
